Liz, I gave you a reco for your dark sky remarks. I went through a period of stargazing a few years back, and I continue to be in favor of limiting light spillage into the sky. I recall a few years ago someone concocted the harebrained idea to send up huge geosynchronous advertising satellites that would have displayed visible advertising in the night sky, obscuring the natural beauty of the stars themselves. Thank goodness that came to nothing, and here's hoping no one ever thinks to desecrate the night sky with such a hideous evil again. I have a pet theory that streetlights cause crime by disrupting the natural rhythms of light and dark that allow us to get a good night's sleep. If we allow ourselves to live in a perpetual "full moon" of brightness, we make ourselves "loony" when we can't access the cycles of deep darkness that we naturally need, and when we lose touch with the passage of seasons as mapped out in the stars. (Yes, I'm being a little facetious, but only a little.)

I don't think the author's message was confusing at all. She is simply saying that sharing grief (in a communal way) is comforting and healing that can happen any place where grief is acknowledged openly.

Why is it that the medium can provide all kinds of fuzzy details about the dead person, and yet can never seem to come up with a clear detail, such as a name? It's always "the letter P", attributed to apparently frequent "static" in the afterlife. And the larger the group of potential "mourners", the easier it is to get a "hit" with statements like "I am hearing from a woman with a 'G' or a 'J' name", or "she says she felt a pain in her chest before she died". Why is it never, and I mean never, something like "I am hearing from a Gladys Jones from Ridgewood NJ, who died 3 years ago of leukemia, and she wants to talk to her daughter Lisa"?

I think when buying a service it does the buyer good to understand the service that they are asking for and get references. I don't think you can go wrong developing your own discernment in the process. Kubler Ross was a breath of fresh air, Pema Chodron is also an interesting Western woman and Tibetan author writing about passage.

I appreciate discussion on an aspect of grief counseling few people consider, Communication with deceased loved ones. However, the author sends a confusing message. Although she engaged in personal research to find if mediums can communicate with deceased persons. She reports she found no veracity to such claims. Then concludes by recommending it may help some grieving loved ones because of what isn't made clear except it will cost money. Her whole story strikes me as dishonest. Either mediums provide meaningful solace through deceased contact or they don't.

I have done my own research in grief recovery using certified mediums from the Windbridge Institute and I'm absolutely convinced consciousness survives death. A medium will tell you they don't control who comes through. Over a few weeks of connecting with several mediums over the phone I contacted 2 family members, and a deceased friend who died under mysterious circumstances in a foreign country. Finally, the medium spoke there's a young man here who says you know him. He had a stone wall fall on him. I had forgotten all about that. My co-worker Mike McGinnis died just that way in a construction accident 37 yrs before. Took me 2 days to remember his name. Hows that for a cold reading.

Perhaps this situation raises different issues, but they are issues for the pregnant women and her partner to deal with. None of the rest of us have standing to intervene.

The only ethical choice is to let the woman decide. People with Downs syndrome can live happy productive lives ... or they can live miserable, pain-filled ones full of heart conditions and extreme mental retardation. We see the best-case scenarios on a regular basis, but not the less-functional, less-healthy outcomes.

Motherhood begins when the pregnant woman says so. The mother-baby bond forms when the woman says so. The bond, if it has formed, may be broken if the woman desires to. This really isn't a difficult thing to see. Treat pregnant women as capable people and it's obvious.

You have to understand that most Down's Syndrome children need LIFELONG care.  Down's Syndrome children are most commonly born to older women; women in their late thirties onward.  If you are forty and have a Down's child, you will need to make provisions for that child as you age, because they, very likely, will not be able to care for themselves and you, very likely, will not be in a position to care for them when you are 80!  This takes money, physical and mental stamina and tremendous patience.  Not everyone feels they are equipped to deal with this situation and, unless those lawmakers volunteer to adopt and care for these kids, the woman, her family and her doctor should have the right to make that decision.

I am totally pro-choice! The pro=lifers are nuts! Well, I thought these were my positions before reading this article (and seeing these comments). The choice crowd must think about the ethics herein... This is not an easy question and a knee jerk condemnation doesn't work.

The goal of routine prenatal screening is to ensure that the fetus develops without major defects. If the mother finds out the child is missing a major organ and will barely survive, sure, abort. Here though, the mother finds out that her child has Down's syndrome. This is a real person. We are really on a slippery slope.

Remember, these mothers did not decide to have an abortion for personal reasons. They screened the fetus out of love. The mother-child relationship was already forming. The test, in a way, is an early act of LOVE. Is it okay to break the bond if they learn that the child has Down's? The mother that took the time to ensure this life was okay and now chooses to no longer love.

This is a very different from how we usually perceive choice, where the rationale tends to revolve around a mother that is not ready to carry or to be a parent.

For me, this type of choice brings up many real ethical questions for liberals like myself. These include the primary goals of prenatal screening, defining the slippery slope of what makes a life meaningful, and the message sent to real parents who love Down's children. Last it begs the question of when does motherhood, as opposed to life, start.

Steve Bolger,

I am glad my parents allowed me to be born. I guess you are having some regrets.
